required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Different Doses of Vitamin D and T Regulatory Cells in Preterm Infants
clinical_study.official_title: A Randomized Controlled Trial on the Effect of 400 vs. 800 IU of Vitamin D on T Regulatory Cells in Preterm Infants

brief_summary.textblock: This study evaluate the effect of two different doses of vitamin D on T-regulatory cells in preterm infants. Half of the subjects receives 400 IU vitamin D and the other half receives 800 IU vitamin D.

detailed_description.textblock: Vitamin D, in addition to its bone mineralization effect, is an immune- modulatory agent. Fetal and premature cellular immunity are generally delayed. Whether vitamin D can enhance cellular immunity by increasing T regulatory cells is unknown. The effect of two different doses of vitamin D; 400 IU and 800 IU will be studied.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.measure: Percent Change in The Number of T Regulatory Cells
primary_outcome.description: Flow cytometry assessment of CD4+ , CD25+ with expression of FOXP3 will be used to identify T Regulatory cells

primary_outcome.measure: Percent Change in The Number of T Regulatory Cells
primary_outcome.description: Flow cytometry assessment of CD4+ , CD25+ with expression of FOXP3 will be used to identify T Regulatory cells

arm_group.description: Subjects in this group receive 400 IU vitamin D daily for 4 weeks.
Subjects in this group receive 800 IU vitamin D daily for 4 weeks.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Preterm infants with gestational age 28-33 weeks
Exclusion Criteria:
- Necrotizing enterocolitis
- Bowel perforation
- Chromosomal anomalies
- Inborn errors of metabolism
- Major congenital anomalies

results_reference.citation: Bozkurt O, Uras N, Sari FN, Atay FY, Sahin S, Alkan AD, Canpolat FE, Oguz SS. Multi-dose vitamin d supplementation in stable very preterm infants: Prospective randomized trial response to three different vitamin D supplementation doses. Early Hum Dev. 2017 Sep;112:54-59. doi: 10.1016/j.earlhumdev.2017.07.016. Epub 2017 Aug 2.
Zittermann A, Dembinski J, Stehle P. Low vitamin D status is associated with low cord blood levels of the immunosuppressive cytokine interleukin-10. Pediatr Allergy Immunol. 2004 Jun;15(3):242-6.
